name: ICNAB
mission: FUND RAISING FOR CHARITIABLE PURPOSES AND KEY INITIATIVES FOR BOSNIAK BASED ISLAMIC CENTERS IN NORTH AMERICA. THIS HELPS KEEP ALL BOSNIAK MOSQUES IN COM...
zakatClaimEvidence: ICNA is a "Zakat eligible" organization. ICNA explicitly states, "Please note that ICNA does collect and distribute Zakaah to the poor and needy, through several of its departments and chapters such as Helping Hand for Relief and Development and ICNA Relief.". ICNA Relief USA also states, "Yes! ICNA Relief ensures that your Zakat and Zakat al-Fitr contributions reach those in need locally and globally" and "Unlike other non-profits, ICNA Relief USA uses your Zakat to help the vulnerable communities here within the United States!". Furthermore, ICNA Relief USA confirms, "ICNA Relief USA uses 100% your Zakat to help vulnerable communities in your locality across the United States through our 7 programs.". (Source: https://www.charitynavigator.org/ein/812169685#financials)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

all_citations.claim: The organization focuses on fundraising for Bosniak Islamic centers and is identified as Zakat-eligible.
The charity reported total revenue of $4,520,145, a program expense ratio of 97.9%, and 9.2 months of working capital.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The charity demonstrates strong financial health and efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by its specific focus on capacity building rather than direct service delivery.
areas_for_improvement: Limited public documentation regarding specific impact metrics for capacity-building programs
Moderate data confidence suggests a need for more transparent third-party reporting

dimension_explanations.alignment: As a Zakat-eligible organization, it offers a medium fit for Muslim donors specifically interested in preserving Bosniak religious identity in North America [1]. The alignment score reflects a specialized religious and cultural cause urgency that may appeal to a specific demographic within the community [2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization maintains a high program expense ratio of 97.9%, directing the vast majority of its $4,520,145 revenue toward its mission [2]. While it shows strong financial management with 9.2 months of working capital, its impact score reflects a focus on capacity building for other centers rather than direct, measurable beneficiary outcomes [1].

strengths: High program expense ratio of 97.9% indicates most funds go directly to initiatives

alignment.explanation: The organization has a <cite id="12">verified zakat program</cite> and serves a niche, underserved community in the <cite id="13">religious and cultural cause area</cite>.
alignment.improvement: The charity could <cite id="12">clarify its zakat allocation policy</cite> by explicitly listing use categories for each of the eight asnaf.

credibility.explanation: Donors can verify the organization's financial health through <cite id="2">Form 990 filings</cite> and its <cite id="8">100% independent board membership</cite>. However, credibility is limited by the <cite id="11">absence of a Candid seal</cite> and lack of third-party impact evaluations.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="10">document a clear theory of change</cite> and publish annual impact reports with specific beneficiary counts.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="4">97.6% program ratio</cite> and <cite id="6">resilient working capital</cite>. While the delivery model is direct, there is <cite id="9">no evidence of outcome tracking</cite> over a multi-year period.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize the preservation of Bosniak Islamic identity in North America and value high financial efficiency over formal impact metrics.
donor_motivations: Want to support the infrastructure of Bosniak Islamic centers
Value organizations with extremely low administrative overhead
Prefer supporting established community-led religious institutions
Seek to fulfill zakat obligations through a culturally specific lens
giving_considerations: Gifts support capacity building rather than direct individual aid
Limited data is available on the specific number of individuals served
The organization is in a high-growth phase with significant funding needs
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking rigorous, third-party verified evidence of social impact or those looking for large-scale international humanitarian relief.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects strong financial reporting but a <cite id="9">total lack of beneficiary counts</cite> or external evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The organization operates on the implicit theory that funding and supporting local Islamic centers will preserve religious heritage and provide community services for the Bosniak diaspora.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the millions of dollars in community funding are effectively sustaining these centers and meeting the spiritual needs of the diaspora.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With <cite id="2">$4.5M in revenue</cite> and a growing network of centers, the organization has a high capacity to absorb more funding for its capital-intensive initiatives.
strategic_priorities: Expand support for Bosniak Islamic centers
Strengthen community initiatives in North America

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="4">97.6% of its total expenses</cite> toward its programs, significantly exceeding the <cite id="7">industry standard of 75%</cite>.
The charity has achieved a <cite id="3">3-year revenue CAGR of 42.2%</cite>, growing from $2.2 million in 2021 to over $4.5 million in 2023.
Maintaining <cite id="6">9.2 months of working capital</cite> provides a high level of financial stability for its member Islamic centers.

strengths_deep_dive: IZBSA's financial model is characterized by extreme directness in its funding flow. By maintaining <cite id="5">zero fundraising costs</cite>, the organization ensures that donor intent is fully realized without the friction of solicitation expenses. This efficiency is paired with a <cite id="8">100% independent board</cite>, which provides oversight for the <cite id="2">$4.5 million in annual contributions</cite>. The organization's ability to scale its revenue by over 100% in two years while keeping administrative costs low suggests a highly effective community-based mobilization strategy.
rich_narrative.summary: Islamska Zajednica Bosnjaka Sjeverne Amerike (IZBSA) serves as the central religious and financial infrastructure for the Bosniak Muslim diaspora across the United States and Canada. The organization focuses on <cite id="1">fundraising for charitable purposes and key initiatives</cite> that sustain Bosniak-based Islamic centers, ensuring that these community hubs can maintain their religious and cultural heritage. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization demonstrated significant growth, reporting <cite id="2">total revenue of $4,520,145</cite>, which represents a <cite id="3">3-year revenue CAGR of 42.2%</cite>. This rapid expansion highlights the increasing trust and mobilization of the Bosniak community in North America. Operationally, the charity maintains an exceptionally lean structure, with a <cite id="4">program expense ratio of 97.9%</cite>, ensuring that nearly all contributions are directed toward community support and religious services rather than administrative overhead. Furthermore, the organization operates with <cite id="5">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, a rare metric that indicates its revenue is generated through community-led efforts and direct contributions rather than costly marketing campaigns. With <cite id="6">9.2 months of working capital</cite> held in working capital, IZBSA maintains a resilient financial position capable of sustaining long-term institutional growth.
